title: Electrochemistry in Lithium-Ion Batteries
summary: A deep dive into the electrochemical principles behind lithium-ion batteries — the technology powering smartphones, electric vehicles, and renewable energy storage.
content:
Case Study: Electrochemistry in Lithium-Ion Batteries

Lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries are ubiquitous in modern technology. Their operation is a direct application of electrochemical principles: oxidation-reduction reactions, half-cells, and electrode potentials.

Electrochemical Fundamentals

A battery converts chemical energy to electrical energy via spontaneous redox reactions. In a Li-ion cell, lithium ions (Li⁺) migrate through an electrolyte between two electrodes. The negative electrode (anode) is typically graphite; the positive electrode (cathode) is a lithium metal oxide such as LiCoO₂.

Half-Cell Reactions

At the anode (oxidation during discharge):
LiC₆ → C₆ + Li⁺ + e⁻

At the cathode (reduction during discharge):
CoO₂ + Li⁺ + e⁻ → LiCoO₂

Overall cell reaction:
LiC₆ + CoO₂ → C₆ + LiCoO₂   E°cell ≈ 3.7 V

Charging and the Nernst Equation

During charging, the reactions are reversed using an external electrical source. The actual cell voltage deviates from the standard electrode potential as the state of charge changes — behavior described by the Nernst equation: E = E° − (RT/nF)lnQ.

Energy Density and Safety

Li-ion batteries offer high energy density (~200 Wh/kg) compared to lead-acid batteries (~35 Wh/kg). However, overcharging or physical damage can cause thermal runaway — an exothermic chain reaction that highlights the importance of battery management systems rooted in electrochemical understanding.
